entries.text: At ZipRecruiter, our goal is to build the best online services for finding and filling jobs. We've grown from 4 to over 100 employees in less than 4 years with zero funding.  We care about code quality and quality of life. To learn more about our business and values, please follow the link above.
entries.title: ZipRecruiter is hiring modern Perl Programmers (Los Angeles or remote in US)

entries.text: We are a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications. We are looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
entries.title: We are Hiring a Senior Perl Software Developer - Grant Street Group

entries.text: It is with great sadness that we learned of the untimely death of Dancer contributor and Perl community member James Aitken. For anybody wishing to help with the funeral costs, the link leads to a funding campaign.
entries.title: James Aitken (LoonyPandora) passed away

entries.text: Neil Bowers points out the advantages of specifying the supported perl versions of your distributions.
entries.title: Specify the min perl version for your distribution

entries.text: Gabor Szabo is the owner of the 'perlprogramming.org' domain, but doesn't really have a use for it. So he's asking if anybody is interested in taking over.
entries.title: perlprogramming.org

entries.text: Type::Tiny is one of those keystone minimal implementation-distribution  that found their way in almost everybody's toolbox.  Toby Inkster announces proudly that it has now reached its v1.0 milestone.
entries.title: Type::Tiny 1.000000 Released

entries.text: Mithaldu let us know that a new version of PPI is out. It's faster, with more documentation, tests, and now live on GitHub!
entries.title: PPI 1.218 has been released - bug fixes, speed optimizations, tests, doc improvements

entries.text: Sinan Unur releases App::multiwhich, a variation of the venerable 'which' command.
entries.title: Just uploaded App::multiwhich in observance of CPAN day

entries.text: BooK announces the arrival of a new CPAN site. It's still very new and very bare, but it might pay to come back and have a look at it in the upcoming weeks.
entries.title: Announcing CPAN.io

entries.text: Database schemas are hard to get right. Ovid tries to help us along the way, and shares a quick checks that is likely to make some of its flaws come out of the woodwork.
entries.title: Quickly Check for Database Design Flaws

entries.text: CPANTesters is the bee's knee, but recently we have seen the rise of Travis CI, a general-purpose testing service.  Neil Bowers shows us here how to use it  for Perl distributions.
entries.title: Try Travis CI with your CPAN distributions

entries.text: Neil Bowers regales us with a break-neck recap of the last 20 years of CPAN.
entries.title: A brief history of CPAN

entries.text: Ovid discusses at a high-level the challenges and intricacies that goes  in writing a MMORPG.
entries.title: Creating an MMORPG in Perl

entries.text: Neil Bowers makes the case for putting your CPAN distribution on GitHub.
entries.title: Put your CPAN distributions on github

entries.text: Richard Elberger discusses how he ported an application from Axis2 to Mojolicious.
entries.title: Our Axis2 to Mojolicious Modernization

entries.text: Lots of changes are coming to Test::Builder.  Chad Granum explains their motivation here.
entries.title: The new Test::Builder - "Why?"

entries.text: Now that the dust is settling on CPAN day, peoples are looking at the scoreboard of releases. Samuel Kaufman draws our attention on Ingy dot Net,  who really went ALL out.
entries.title: CPAN Day winner?

entries.text: Richard Elberger is the new maintainer of Net::Gnats, an interface to the GNU Gnats bug tracking system.
entries.title: Net::Gnats and GNU Gnats and Gnatsweb

entries.text: Having it is only half the battle: one has to also be able to find it.  Mike Greb shares his tricks to find what he's looking for in a local CPAN mirror.
entries.title: Finding Stuff In Your Local CPAN Mirror

entries.text: So your little Catalyst application is not so little anymore, and it has reached a size where it becomes unwieldy and should be fragmented in smaller, separate parts. Dave Wood has been there, and tells us how he proceeded.
entries.title: Splitting a Catalyst App and recombining it with Plack::Builder

entries.title: Uploading Your First Module to CPAN

header: On August 15th CPAN Day, thanks to the endless promotion of Neil Bowers and others, the anniversary of the birth of CPAN was celebrated. The libations were true to form: over 775 releases were made by 107 authors. Flash in the pan? Beginning of a tradition? We'll have to wait until next year to find out. In the meantime, we can sit back, relax, and enjoy this tsunami of new releases. ~ `/anick
subject: Happy Belated CPAN Day!
